Stage 1 Update:

Post Anchorage, Boba has two green slices on L2Beat‚Äôs security pie.

In addition to the data availability slice, the self-sequencing slice turned green. üßµüëá
Data availability:

All data required for proofs is published onchain.

The full system state can be reconstructed from data posted as blobs or calldata, ensuring the data remains available for a sufficient period of time.
Self-sequencing:

Users can always force transaction inclusion.

Anyone can submit transactions directly to L1, bypassing the sequencer.

These forced transactions are automatically included in the L2 chain, ensuring censorship resistance and guaranteed inclusion even if the sequencer censors or goes offline.
Now, what's the deal with stage 0 and stage 1?

Under the current OP Stack permissioned fraud proof model, only a single permissioned actor is able to submit proofs.

L2Beat requires at least 5 external actors.

This will get Boba back onto the now limited rollups page.
To reach Stage 1, the current bonded capital requirement is hundreds of ETH per game.

Games can be launched concurrently, meaning a challenger with resources can open many games in a resource exhaustion attack (a.k.a. a Proof of Whale attack). 
Furthermore, defenders must have more resources than the attacker.

Each game has up to 74 levels (0-73).

Starting with .08 ETH, an attacker can open a claim which then scales exponentially by a factor of 1.09493 each level.
Since defenders would inherently go second, they pay that 9% premium each level.

Attackers would post 330.04 ETH per game.

Defenders would post 361.38 ETH per game.

If the defenders run out of capital to post as bond, they can lose by default.
There are a few potential paths being considered to solve this, once available:

-A potential @SuperchainEco challenger fund.

-ZK validity-based approaches from teams like @SuccinctLabs
Boba is committed to adding to the current green slices. Strong security and decentralization remains a top priority.

The best days are ahead.

2025 Year in Review: While Crypto Talked, Celo Delivered

It was a year of compounding adoption, heralding proof over promises. Not only did Celo‚Äôs mission go mainstream, the metrics made it obvious

Keep reading @RegenRene's end-of-year letter for the highlights ‚Üì 
This year, most of crypto cycled through familiar narratives, hot takes & resurfaced debates, like L1s vs. L2s (spoiler alert: the latter will win), Celo was hyperfocused on something less exciting in the short term, but far more important in the long term: proof 
We shipped milestone infra, like our L2 migration, and reached all-time adoption highs, becoming the #1 L2 in DAUs ahead of @Base and @Worldcoin, and crypto‚Äôs #1 transport layer for USDT by WAUs ahead of @TronDAO, thanks to everyday users in emerging markets 
Crypto went mainstream, flooded w/ corporatized chains & countless ‚Äúlogo x logo‚Äù announcements, we got something rare: PMF & a roaring distribution engine

Built from the ground up, hand-in-hand with partners like @Opera, architects of @MiniPay, crypto‚Äôs fastest growing use case https://twitter.com/1429725410003062785/status/1997779252758921705
Our teams have quietly delivered what countless projects have failed to achieve. Not ideas. Not intentions. Not spectacle masquerading as progress, or grandstanding product reveals engineered for the cameras and timeline rather than for the benefit of everyday users https://twitter.com/231208649/status/1945602337533562891
We're talking about usage that repeats, product that becomes habit

Not only have we cracked the code to find product-market fit, what the industry has been starved for, we've done this across the Global South for the forest conservationist in √ëuiyanzhi, Colombia, the local merchant in Nairobi, Kenya, and the crypto builder in Lagos, Nigeria, among many others
Networks grow because the experience is better & the plumbing (boringly) works, not because a story is louder

For all the shiny projects that captured mindshare & the trends du jour only to fizzle out, our staying power is a testament to prioritizing mission over marketing, verifiable usage over hype
2025 was the year of compounding adoption, when impact became proof:

‚Üí 790K peak daily active users (#1 L2 for DAUs)
‚Üí 3.3M+ peak weekly active users of USDT (#1 chain)
‚Üí 5.2M+ new users in 2025 (79% first-time users)
‚Üí $65.9B+ stablecoin volume YTD (+142% vs 2024) 
This adoption didn‚Äôt happen by accident. It was earned day to day through deliberate choices, difficult engineering, and a commitment to meet users where they are

One of the most important things we did this year‚Äì‚Äìmigrating to an @Ethereum Layer 2‚Äì‚Äìwas also the least visible to most users
Yet we chose to do the hard thing, crossing a defining threshold and setting a standard for others to follow suit. We returned home to Ethereum with 100+ day-one partners, unlocking:

‚Üí Deeper Ethereum alignment
‚Üí Easier interoperability and integration paths
‚Üí A foundation built for scaling without compromising user experience
‚Üí Costs reduction of 99.8%, supercharging chain revenue by 10x

The experience didn‚Äôt have to change for users or builders. Celo remained mobile-first, low-cost, fast, and practical
We stopped talking about crypto as a ‚Äúfeature,‚Äù but an assumption, because we knew that for the mission to go mainstream, the product had to be invisible. We saw more moments where:

‚Üí Someone sends money across a border and doesn‚Äôt think about settlement
‚Üí Someone pays or gets paid and doesn‚Äôt think about fees
‚Üí Someone uses a mini app and doesn‚Äôt think about chain selection
‚Üí Someone saves in a stable asset and doesn‚Äôt think about volatility

That‚Äôs not just adoption, it‚Äôs normalization
Celo has always believed that the ‚Äúreal world‚Äù isn‚Äôt niche, but a destination. Impact isn‚Äôt about idealism or virtue signaling, but concrete execution and practice. This year, we turned aspirational belief into a platform advantage, with a plan to evolve our tokenomics to support the network‚Äôs tremendous growth
Distribution strengthened through projects #BuiltOnCelo like @Opera's stablecoin wallet @MiniPay, with 11M+ wallets & 300M+ transactions processed

As we extend our partnership, we aim to bring MiniPay to Opera's 300M+ users as we work toward onboarding 1 billion people to the digital economy by 2030
DeFi building blocks also became stronger through integrations of @Aave v3, @VelodromeFi & @Uniswap v4, joining @chainlink, @CurveFinance, @Bancor, while Self-verified pools pushed stablecoin liquidity even deeper https://twitter.com/1511770076738990082/status/1907848272603132226
@SelfProtocol's @EthDenver launch was a category-defining breakthrough: introducing a zk-powered proof-of-humanity & identity layer leveraging government-issued biometric passports & IDs

Self is partnered w/ @GoogleCloud, @aave, @velodrome & now supports India's Aadhaar ID https://twitter.com/1882843792488980481/status/1948005278554702005
Building on this massive distribution for 2026, we're scaling responsibly toward a trillion-dollar onchain economy:

‚Üí Making stablecoin payments feel native everywhere
‚Üí Expanding the mini-app economy
‚Üí Strengthening rails for trust & safety
Not because we‚Äôre better at narratives, but because we‚Äôve been obsessed with the same thing for years: making the real world the center of our design‚Äì‚Äìa focal point that the industry‚Äôs crypto OGs recognize and respect

The core innovation is PeerDAS.

Validators no longer need to download ALL rollup data. Instead, they verify availability by sampling small portions (12.5%) removing a major scalability bottleneck.
Why this matters:

Ethereum can support far more rollup data without forcing validators into enterprise-grade hardware, keeping home stakers viable and decentralization intact.
Fusaka also improves L1 capacity and predictability.

More gas per block, smoother blob fees, and EVM upgrades for modern authentication and account abstraction.
What this means for Zircuit:

Lower blob costs, higher throughput, better developer tooling, and more predictable operating costs.
Fusaka changes how Ethereum scales and it directly affects rollups like Zircuit.
